column1: Bologoye (Russian: Болого́е) is a town and the administrative center of Bologovsky District in Tver Oblast
column3: as well as a major railway hub. It is located approximately halfway between Moscow and St. Petersburg on the railway route connecting the two cities. Population: 23

column1: The name of the town derives from the name of nearby Lake Bologoye.
The first mention of Bologoye in historic records dates back to 1495
column2: which is considered its year of foundation. In the course of the administrative reform carried out in 1708 by Peter the Great
column3: Bologoye was included into the Ingermanland Governorate (known since 1710 as the St. Petersburg Governorate). In 1727

column5: it became a part of Valdaysky Uyezd of Novgorod Viceroyalty. In 1796
column6: the viceroyalty was transformed into Novgorod Governorate.In 1851
column7: Bologoye became a station of the Moscow – Saint Petersburg Railway. In the second half of the 19th century
column8: the Rybinsk–Pskov–Vindava railway passed through Bologoye
column9: turning it into a large railway junction. Railway-related industries have contributed significantly to the town's growth.
